Package projects.graph

Class AdjacencyMatrixGraph

  • java.lang.Object
    • projects.graph.AdjacencyMatrixGraph
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    Graph
    public class AdjacencyMatrixGraph
extends java.lang.Object
implements Graph

    AdjacencyMatrixGraph is a Graph implemented as an adjacency matrix. An adjacency matrix is a V x V matrix where M(i, j) is the weight of the edge from i to j. If there is no edge between i and j, the weight should be zero.

    Adjacency matrices answer isConnected(int, int) in O(1) time. Insertion and deletion of edges, as well as retrieval of the weight of a given edge are all O(1) operations as well. Retrieval of all neighbors of a given node happens in O(V) time.

    The main drawbacks of adjacency matrices are:

    1. They occupy O(V^2) contiguous memory space, which for sparse graphs can be a significant memory footprint.
    2. addNode() runs in O(V^2) time, since new array storage needs to be allocated for the extra row and column, and the old data need be copied to the new array.
    Author:
    --- YOUR NAME HERE! ---
    See Also:
    Graph, SparseAdjacencyMatrixGraph, AdjacencyListGraph

      • addNode

        public void addNode()
        Description copied from interface: Graph

        Add a new node to the graph. The node will be characterized by its index of insertion, such that the first time this method is called, a node with index ' 0 ' is stored in the graph, the second one we will store a node with index 1, etc, etc.

        Specified by:
        addNode in interface Graph

      • addEdge

        public void addEdge​(int source,
                    int target,
                    int weight)
        Description copied from interface: Graph

        Adds an edge from node source to node target in the graph, attaching to it weight weight. In this implementation, we don't allow weights to be negative. If a negative weight is provided, the method should throw a RuntimeException. If the edge already exists, its weight should be updated to the parameter value.

        If either source or target don't exist in the graph, the behavior is undefined. This means that you can do whatever you want, as long as you don't store extra edges or nodes in the graph. You can throw a RuntimeException, return null, print a message, anything. We do not test for this case.

        We treat the addition of a weight with zero weight exactly the same way we would treat the deletion of an edge through Graph.deleteEdge(int, int). So, the calls add(i, j, 0) and deleteEdge(i, j) are equivalent.

        Specified by:
        addEdge in interface Graph
        Parameters:
        source - The source node of the edge.
        target - The "sink" node of the edge.
        weight - The weight of the edge.

      • deleteEdge

        public void deleteEdge​(int source,
                       int target)
        Description copied from interface: Graph

        Delete the edge from source to target. If the edge does not exist, or if either node does not exist in the graph, no action should be performed.

        We would like to particularly stress that removing an edge does not in any way imply removing its constituent nodes, even if the nodes end up being singleton disconnected components!

        Specified by:
        deleteEdge in interface Graph
        Parameters:
        source - The source node of the edge.
        target - The "sink" node of the edge.

      • isConnected

        public boolean isConnected​(int source,
                           int target)
        Description copied from interface: Graph

        Queries the graph about the existence of an edge from source to target. If either source or target are not contained by the graph, then the edge itself cannot possibly exist.

        Specified by:
        isConnected in interface Graph
        Parameters:
        source - The source node of the edge.
        target - The " sink " of the edge.
        Returns:
        true if, and only if, source, target and the edge source->target all exist in the graph, false otherwise.

      • getNeighbors

        public java.util.Set<java.lang.Integer> getNeighbors​(int node)
        Description copied from interface: Graph

        Retrieves the "neighbor" nodes of the provided node, i.e all the nodes to which it is connected (whether it is the source OR sink). If the node does not exist in the graph, the behavior is undefined; you can do whatever you want (and that helps you debug!) and we don't test for it. If the node does exist in the graph but it has no neighbors, the returned Set should be non-null, but empty (size 0).

        Specified by:
        getNeighbors in interface Graph
        Parameters:
        node - The node to retrieve the neighbors of.
        Returns:
        A Set of all nodes to which node is incident (whether it is the source OR sink).

      • shortestPath

        public java.util.List<java.lang.Integer> shortestPath​(int source,
                                                      int target)
        Description copied from interface: Graph

        Returns the shortest path between source and target in the graph, as defined by the sum of the weights of all edges that connect source and target. Since we don't allow negative edges, you can implement this with either Dijkstra's or the Bellman-Ford algorithm, whichever one you prefer! The code, of course, will have to be your own (no taking ready-made libraries out there, whether they are part of Oracle's standard library or not).

        If either source or target are not part of the graph, the behavior is undefined (we don't test for this case).

        An important note: since this class represents directed graphs, even if source == target, there may not even exist a path that connects source and target.

        Specified by:
        shortestPath in interface Graph
        Parameters:
        source - The source node of the edge.
        target - The " sink " node of the edge.
        Returns:
        A List

      • toSparseAdjacencyMatrixGraph

        public SparseAdjacencyMatrixGraph toSparseAdjacencyMatrixGraph()

        Returns a sparsified representation of the adjacency matrix, i.e a linked list of its non-null elements (non-zero, in this case) and their coordinates. The matrix should be scanned in row-major order to populate the elements of the list (and we test for proper element insertion order!).

        Returns:
        A SparseAdjacencyMatrixGraph instance.

      • toAdjacencyListGraph

        public AdjacencyListGraph toAdjacencyListGraph()

        Returns a representation of the Graph as an AdjacencyListGraph. Remember that an AdjacencyListGraph is implemented as an array of linked lists, where A(i) is a linked list containing the neighbors of node i. Remember that an AdjacencyListGraph is implemented as an array of linked lists, where A(i) is a linked list containing the neighbors of node i.

        Returns:
        An AdjacencyListGraph instance.
